The housing facilities are not protecting the birds from injury or restricting other animals from entering that may negatively
affect the welfare of the birds within the enclosure.
Review of facility records indicate that on 25-March-2025 there was a call duck death. The outdoor enclosure housing the
call duck is not fully enclosed and has an open top. Keeper notes state that the animal death was attributed to a predator
with the presence of blood and a pile of feathers just outside of the open top pen. It was also noted that a trap was set.
However, further conversations with facility representatives indicated that an animal was not captured.
Review of facility records indicate that on 05-April-2025 there was a Cockatiel Death. Keeper notes state that the body of
the animal was half eaten and was believed to have been attacked by a rat. Additionally, records state on 30-March-2025
there was an additional Cockatiel death. Keeper notes state that the body was found with wounds on the head and major
feather loss. The facility filled in holes along the base of the indoor winter holding enclosure and set traps to negate any
further predation.
Failure to ensure that all enclosures protect the birds from injury and restrict other animals from entering can result in
stress, injury, or death to the birds.
Correct by ensuring that enclosures are designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of
bird housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from
entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Housing facilities must employ security measures that
contain all birds securely. Such measures may include safety doors, entry/exit doors to the primary enclosure that are
double-door, or other equivalent systems designed to prevent escape of the birds. Birds that are flight-restricted or cannot
fly and are allowed to roam free within the housing facility or a portion thereof must have access to safety pens,
enclosures, or other areas that offer the birds protection during overnight periods and at times when their activities are not
monitored.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 16-June-2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity may continue at all regulated sites until expiration of the current license. At that time, conducting
regulated activity from any site without a valid USDA license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
